sentences.text: Hello and welcome to the explosive strength bonus course.
In the next few lessons, you're going to build your explosive strength and power in your lower body to perfectly supplement your footwork skills.
Technique is by far the biggest factor to having good footwork, and that's something I stressed multiple times throughout the main course.
But building explosive strength on top of that technical foundation, well, that's just the icing on the cake.
The pro players recognise this very well.
They painstakingly spent hours working on their technique to get every single movement down to a tee, but they also spend time working on their physical development.
And that's why Chen Long, for example, has legs that look like this.
No joke, huh?
Why is this the case?
Well, Bambin is an extremely explosive sport and requires powerful fast Twitch muscle fibres.
If you don't know your muscles are made out of both fast Twitch and slow Twitch muscle fibres.
Slow Twitch muscle fibres are responsible for low intensity endurance activities such as running a marathon.
Fast Twitch muscle fibres, on the other hand, are responsible for the short but powerful bursts of movement, such as sprinting, a 100 metre race.
Good footwork and badminton as a whole does utilise both of these two types of muscle fibre.
But in this bonus course, we're going to focus specifically on the fast switch muscles.
Hence the name explosive strength.
That's exactly what the fast switch muscle fibres are responsible for.
If you watch any pro player's footwork, there are many instances where they change their speed in a split second and explosively accelerate towards the shuttle.
This is what Jill Clarke often refers to as injecting speed into the rally.
It's an incredibly important aspect of high level bandwidth and both on the attack and on the defence.
If you don't vary the speed of your movement like this, you end up playing at one pace the entire time.
Not only is this incredibly predictable, it also puts you in a position where you can't really win rallies, you can just hope for your opponent to lose them.
That's clearly not a great place to be.
That being said, I do want to stress that these pro players are extremely proficient in their technique.
Each movement pattern has been refined for years or even decades, and yet they still work every single day to improve their technique.
So for you, I would not recommend working on this bonus course until you have at least completed the main footwork fasting course and you feel proficient in your footwork.
Explosive strength is a great supplement to technique, but it is absolutely not a replacement.
If one player has good technique but bad strength and another has good strength but bad technique, there wouldn't even be a competition.
The technical player would win every time.
So spend the majority of your time learning and developing technique.
That's where you'll see the biggest improvement in the shortest amount of time.
Only when you feel confident should you then start dedicating more time to strength training.

If you don't get this prioritisation right and start spending hours in the gym before your technique is fluent Then you're just going to waste a lot of time without seeing the results that you're after.
But if you get this right then you will absolutely skyrocket your progress.
I can say that so confidently because that's exactly what happened to me.
I can still vividly picture the first time I added strength training into my routine.
I signed up for a gym membership the day I turned 16.
Since that was the minimum age requirement I didn't really know what I was doing but I messed around with some of the exercises and very quickly I started to see it translate to my damaged game.
It took me by surprise how quickly I could notice the effects on court.
At this point my footwork was already pretty good.
I was fluent with the technique and could move decently well around the court but after doing strength training it was a whole different experience.
It was as if I was wearing weighted training gear the entire time and I had finally taken them off.
I felt so much lighter.
I felt agile.
I felt powerful.
Moving around the court just felt easier.
It's a difficult feeling to describe and I don't think I'm doing a very good job with my words.
It's really something you have to experience for yourself.
And for the record, when I started doing this I was just a skinny 16 year old with no real knowledge of how to lift weight or train strength.
Since then, I've spent a lot of time in the gym and even took a few years away from bambutton to compete in Olympic weightlifting, a very technical and explosive sport.
My point is I was able to see good improvements in my badminton Even though I was just messing around in the gym with no real clue what I was doing.
Since you have access to this bonus course And I'll be guiding you with the knowledge that I've developed over several years, you will see even bigger results.
Excited good.
I'll see you in the next lesson where I'll take you through the key principles of building explosive strength.
